history.content:
great question! My suggestion is to schedule everything. https://www.allencheng.com/deep-work-cal-newport-book-summary-pdf/ This book by Cal Newport, Deep Work, can help you rethink the "study all night" mentality that a lot of people here have. In fact, the most successful people live more balanced lives! This semester I have slept >8 hours every day, and stop working at a certain time every day. I think that this one thing alone will have the biggest impact on your life, which is just to use time more wisely even before thinking about optimizing the time itself. 

New person:  I 100% agree with the person above.  When it starts getting late and I start getting tired, the most important thing that I do is I set my alarm for early enough so that I will have more time in the morning and I go to sleep.  Many times, the thing I was struggling with the night before comes easily in the morning.  This is not only a strategy I've used for CS classes, but also upper div and graduate Math classes where I'm working on tough proofs.  It's so so much more important than people give it credit.  I also just think that there's no one way to "avoid procrastination."  You really just have to force yourself not to procrastinate.  Sometimes that means you have an uncomfortable week or day where you're behind on one thing and really want to push back something else.  For me, those are the days when I force myself to interleave the urgent work and the less urgent work.  If I HAVE to get the urgent work done by the end of the night, but I make sure I get some of the other thing done when, say, I get stuck on the urgent thing (or just by setting a timer to tell me to switch) then sure I might feel uncomfortable but the next day I'm not behind on yet another thing.

These are just a few strategies I use, but plenty of people also benefit from more common things like light music / rain noise while they work, varying the light levels, their study spots, going outside to study and code, etc.  If you haven't tried these they might be easier to implement first.  My strategies might take some getting used to and might not be for everyone, but just like anything, once I'd done them a few times they've felt natural and comfortable for me.

great question! My suggestion is to schedule everything. https://www.allencheng.com/deep-work-cal-newport-book-summary-pdf/ This book by Cal Newport, Deep Work, can help you rethink the "study all night" mentality that a lot of people here have. In fact, the most successful people live more balanced lives! This semester I have slept >8 hours every day, and stop working at a certain time every day. I think that this one thing alone will have the biggest impact on your life, which is just to use time more wisely even before thinking about optimizing the time itself.

Hi!

As a CS major here, it's been a huge struggle to stay on top of my workload and use my time productively. I'm not sure if this is the right place to ask this question but I know many Berkeley EECS students take on crazy amounts of work and I wanted to hear what general strategies people have developed to cope with this.

What helps you all stay on task, avoid procrastination, and make the most of your stacked schedules? Thanks :) please delete if this isn't relevant
history.subject: Advice on Productivity/Managing Workload
